metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

generationDetails.description: Each lesson generated as many valid questions as possible

questions.question: Which option shows the layers of Earth in the correct order from the surface to the centre?

answers.content: Crust → Mantle → Outer core → Inner core
answers.explanation: This is the accepted scientific sequence moving inward.

answers.content: Mantle → Crust → Inner core → Outer core
answers.explanation: The crust is the outermost layer and the cores are deepest.

answers.content: Crust → Outer core → Mantle → Inner core
answers.explanation: The mantle lies directly beneath the crust.

answers.content: Inner core → Outer core → Mantle → Crust
answers.explanation: This order is inside-out.

questions.question: Why is Earth’s inner core solid even though it is as hot as the surface of the Sun?

answers.content: It is made of rock instead of metal.
answers.explanation: Both cores are mostly iron and nickel.

answers.content: Immense pressure at the centre keeps the particles tightly packed.
answers.explanation: High pressure prevents the metal from melting despite the temperature.

answers.content: The inner core receives no heat from the mantle.
answers.explanation: Heat is conducted from surrounding layers.

answers.content: Gravity removes heat from the inner core.
answers.explanation: Gravity does not remove heat.

questions.question: Which layer is responsible for the slow convection currents that drive plate movement at Earth’s surface?

answers.content: Crust
answers.explanation: The crust is brittle and cool.

answers.content: Mantle
answers.explanation: The semi-solid mantle circulates slowly, moving the plates above.

answers.content: Outer core
answers.explanation: The outer core is liquid metal, not rock.

answers.content: Inner core
answers.explanation: The inner core does not convect like the mantle.

questions.question: Describe two differences between the outer core and the inner core.

answers.content: Any two of: (1) State of matter – outer core is liquid, inner core is solid; (2) Temperature – both are hot but outer core slightly cooler; (3) Position – outer core surrounds the inner core.

questions.question: What is the approximate average thickness of Earth’s crust?

answers.explanation: Oceanic crust averages ~5–10 km; continental can be up to ~70 km.
Those values relate more to the upper mantle.
This range refers to the outer core.
This is close to the entire radius of Earth, not just the crust.

questions.question: Explain why scientists use models, such as play-dough spheres, to teach about Earth’s internal structure.

answers.content: Models make invisible or unreachable structures visible, allow students to visualise relative size and arrangement of layers, and simplify complex information for clearer understanding.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram of Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. Include one annotation that describes the temperature trend from the crust to the inner core.

answers.content: Diagram contains: (1) correct sequence of four layers (1 mark); (2) clear labels (1 mark); (3) distinct colours or shading (1 mark); (4) annotation noting temperature increases with depth (1 mark); (5) overall accuracy/neatness (1 mark).

questions.question: Which statement best describes the crust compared with the mantle?

answers.content: The crust is hotter and denser than the mantle.
answers.explanation: The mantle is hotter and generally denser.

answers.content: The crust is thinner and cooler than the mantle.
answers.explanation: This is why we live on the crust rather than within the mantle.

answers.content: Both crust and mantle are liquid.
answers.explanation: The crust is solid; the mantle is mostly semi-solid rock.

answers.content: The mantle lies above the crust.
answers.explanation: The mantle is below the crust.

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes on Earth?

answers.content: The sudden release of energy when two tectonic plates become stuck and then slip
answers.explanation: When plates grind against or collide with one another, pressure builds until it is released as seismic energy, causing an earthquake.

answers.content: Large waves generated by strong winds at sea
Volcanic ash blocking sunlight
Excess heat from Earth’s inner core expanding the crust

questions.question: Using the causal connective ‘so’, write one sentence that explains how the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake changed the coastline.

answers.content: Sample: "The earthquake struck, so the land rose up and changed the shape of the coastline."
answers.explanation: Sentence must contain the conjunction ‘so’ linking cause (earthquake) and effect (land rose/ coastline changed).

questions.question: In the Mars bar model demonstrated in class, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s rigid crust?

answers.content: The hard chocolate coating on the outside
answers.explanation: The solid outer chocolate layer models the brittle crust that cracks during plate movement.

answers.content: The soft caramel layer
The nougat centre
The wrapper around the bar

questions.question: Which year did the earthquake discussed in the lesson strike Japan’s Noto Peninsula?

answers.explanation: The lesson text refers to the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake.

questions.question: When an earthquake’s epicentre is located on the ocean floor, what natural hazard can it generate?

answers.content: A tsunami
answers.explanation: Seafloor displacement pushes water upwards, producing powerful tsunami waves.

answers.content: A cyclone
A drought
A sandstorm

questions.question: Give TWO ways an earthquake can rapidly change a landscape, using scientific vocabulary from the lesson.

answers.content: Sample answers: 1) It can uplift land, creating new cliffs or raising coastlines. 2) It can fracture roads and buildings, producing deep surface cracks and ground deformation.
answers.explanation: Accept any two accurate landscape changes such as uplift, subsidence, ground fissures, landslides, collapse of built structures, etc.

questions.question: Which statement best explains why most volcanoes are found at the edges of tectonic plates?

answers.content: The edges are the coldest parts of Earth’s crust.
Magma can rise more easily where plates move apart or collide, creating weak spots.
answers.explanation: Plate boundaries contain fractures that allow magma to reach the surface.

answers.content: Gravity is weaker at plate boundaries.
There is more water at plate edges, which melts the rock.

questions.question: During the model eruption in Activity 3, the foaming mixture that overflowed from the jar represented which real-world substance?

answers.content: Ash cloud
Magma chamber
Lava flowing down the volcano
answers.explanation: Once magma reaches the surface it becomes lava.

answers.content: Solidified rock layers

questions.question: Give ONE positive and ONE negative effect that a volcanic eruption can have on the landscape.

answers.content:
Positive: New, fertile soil is created for plants.
Negative: Nearby towns can be buried under ash and lava.
answers.explanation: Answers will vary but must include at least one constructive and one destructive consequence.

questions.question: Archaeologists learned about ancient Roman daily life from items preserved in Pompeii. Which discovery specifically showed what people ate?

answers.content: Public baths
Loaves of bread still in ovens
answers.explanation: Carbonised bread revealed the type of food being prepared the morning of the eruption.

answers.content: Gladiator training school
Amphitheatre seating

questions.question: Draw and label a simple diagram showing how a volcanic eruption can lead to the formation of new land. Include arrows or labels for: magma chamber, vent, lava flow, and the new land created.

answers.content: Diagram includes the four requested labels and clearly shows lava building up new land beyond the vent.
answers.explanation: Use for marking reference.

questions.question: What is the BEST definition of weathering?

answers.content: The movement of broken rock pieces to a new place
answers.explanation: That describes erosion, not weathering.

answers.content: The breaking down of rocks into smaller pieces by natural forces
answers.explanation: Weathering refers to processes that break down rocks; erosion is the transport of those pieces.

answers.content: Molten rock erupting from a volcano
answers.explanation: That is volcanic activity, not weathering.

answers.content: Earth’s revolution around the Sun
answers.explanation: This is an astronomical motion, unrelated to weathering.

questions.question: Which trio lists ONLY agents of weathering explored in this lesson?

answers.content: Wind, moving water, plants
answers.explanation: These three were the focus agents studied.

answers.content: Gravity, sunlight, icebergs
answers.explanation: These are not the three agents highlighted.

answers.content: Animals, lightning, plate tectonics
answers.explanation: Not all of these are agents of weathering in this lesson.

answers.content: Clouds, rainbows, tides
answers.explanation: These were not identified as weathering agents here.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube investigation, shaking the jar represented which natural process?

answers.content: Wind blowing sand against rocks
answers.explanation: The cubes collided like sand grains driven by wind.

answers.content: Ice wedging inside cracks
answers.explanation: No freezing or expansion was involved.

answers.content: Plant roots pushing into rock
answers.explanation: Roots were not present in the model.

answers.content: A volcanic eruption
answers.explanation: The model did not simulate volcanic activity.

questions.question: Why were the rocks (or sugar cubes) placed on black paper before and after shaking?

answers.content: To absorb heat from the Sun
answers.explanation: Heating the sample was not part of the procedure.

answers.content: To make it easier to see tiny white fragments produced by weathering
answers.explanation: The dark background provides contrast so small pieces are visible.

answers.content: To stop moisture being absorbed
answers.explanation: Moisture control was not the reason.

answers.content: Because black paper is stronger than white paper
answers.explanation: Paper strength was irrelevant; visibility was the goal.

questions.question: Which causal connective is used in the model paragraph but was NOT explicitly taught in lessons 2 or 3?

answers.content: so
answers.explanation: "so" was taught earlier.

answers.content: as a result
answers.explanation: "as a result" was taught earlier.

answers.content: due to
answers.explanation: The paragraph introduced the connective "due to".

answers.content: because
answers.explanation: "because" did not appear in the paragraph given.

questions.question: Explain, in one or two sentences, how plant roots contribute to the weathering of rock.

answers.content: Roots grow into small cracks in rocks and exert pressure as they expand, prising the rock apart and breaking it into smaller pieces.
answers.explanation: Answer must mention roots entering cracks and exerting force that breaks the rock.

questions.question: Over a very long time, a jagged coastal cliff has become smoother and rounded. Which agent of weathering most likely caused this change?

answers.content: Moving water from waves
answers.explanation: Wave action repeatedly strikes the rock, abrading its surface.

answers.content: Wind carrying desert sand
answers.explanation: Wind abrasion is less dominant on wave-washed cliffs.

answers.content: Glacial ice
answers.explanation: Glaciers are not usually present on coastal cliffs.

answers.content: Plant acid from rainforest roots
answers.explanation: Plant weathering is less significant on bare coastal rock faces.

questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly compares weathering and erosion?

answers.content: Weathering breaks down rock; erosion transports the broken material.
answers.explanation: This is the correct distinction.

answers.content: Weathering builds up new landforms while erosion destroys them.
answers.explanation: Neither process builds new rock; deposition builds landforms.

answers.content: Erosion happens only in deserts, while weathering happens everywhere.
answers.explanation: Erosion can happen in many environments.

answers.content: They are two words for the exact same process.
answers.explanation: They are related but different processes.

questions.question: Describe TWO observations you would record after shaking the jar of sandstone pieces for two minutes.

answers.content: Possible observations: (1) The sandstone pieces are smaller and have more rounded edges. (2) Fine grains or dust have collected on the black paper.
answers.explanation: Students should note size/shape change and presence of debris indicating weathering.

questions.question: Why does natural weathering of large boulders usually take thousands of years, whereas the classroom investigation showed changes in minutes?

answers.content: The investigation used much softer material and applied continuous, intense force in a short time.
answers.explanation: Sugar or soft rock plus vigorous shaking accelerates the process compared with gentle natural forces.

answers.content: Real rocks cannot be weathered by any natural force.
answers.explanation: Rocks are weathered in nature, just slowly.

answers.content: Weathering only happens indoors.
answers.explanation: Weathering is a natural outdoor process.

answers.content: Time in nature moves more slowly than time in the classroom.
answers.explanation: Time passes at the same rate; the difference is force and material hardness.

questions.question: In the investigation you carried out, what single variable was changed to keep the test fair?

answers.content: The amount of sand in each tray
answers.explanation: All trays used the same amount of damp sand.

answers.content: The angle (slope) of the tray
answers.explanation: Only the slope was changed – one flat, one gentle and one steep – to test its effect on erosion.

answers.content: The volume of water poured
answers.explanation: The same amount of water was poured into each tray.

answers.content: The length of the river you drew
answers.explanation: Each tray had a river of the same length and shape.

questions.question: Which tray showed the greatest amount of erosion, according to the expected scientific explanation?

answers.content: Tray 1 – flat surface
answers.explanation: The water moved slowest on the flat tray, so the least erosion was expected.

answers.content: Tray 2 – gentle slope
answers.explanation: Erosion occurred, but not as much as on the steep slope.

answers.content: Tray 3 – steep slope
answers.explanation: Water flowed fastest on the steep slope, increasing its force and causing the most erosion.

answers.content: All trays eroded equally
answers.explanation: Rate of erosion depended on water speed, which differed between trays.

questions.question: Erosion is BEST described as:

answers.content: The breaking of rocks into smaller pieces
answers.explanation: That describes weathering.

answers.content: The movement of rocks, soil and sand to a new place
answers.explanation: Erosion transports the weathered material.

answers.content: The cooling of molten rock
answers.explanation: That is solidification of lava or magma.

answers.content: The settling of sediment in a river delta
answers.explanation: That describes deposition, which follows erosion.

questions.question: Why does faster-moving water cause more erosion?

answers.content: It contains more dissolved minerals
answers.explanation: Mineral content does not control erosive power.

answers.content: It has greater force and can carry more sediment
answers.explanation: Higher speed increases kinetic energy, enabling the water to pick up and transport more particles.

answers.content: Faster water is always warmer
answers.explanation: Temperature is unrelated to flow speed in this context.

answers.content: It reduces friction with the river bed
answers.explanation: Friction is still present; the key factor is increased force.

questions.question: Name TWO natural forces that can cause erosion other than moving water.

answers.content: Wind and ice (glaciers)
answers.explanation: Accept any two of: wind, ice/glaciers, gravity/mass movement, waves, living things (e.g., plant roots, burrowing animals).

questions.question: In the Dreaming story ‘Super Snake’, what type of physical feature (landform) did Super Snake create?

answers.content: A river (accept: winding river, waterway, channel)
answers.explanation: Super Snake’s movements carved out river channels in the story.

questions.question: Which statement correctly links weathering and erosion?

answers.content: Weathering moves rock fragments; erosion breaks them apart.
answers.explanation: This reverses the definitions.

answers.content: Weathering breaks rock apart; erosion transports the fragments elsewhere.
answers.explanation: This shows the correct sequence: break first, move second.

answers.content: Weathering and erosion are exactly the same process.
answers.explanation: They are related but different.

answers.content: Erosion only happens underground while weathering happens on the surface.
answers.explanation: Both processes usually occur at or near Earth’s surface.

questions.question: Explain why keeping the amount of water the same in each tray was important for this investigation.

answers.content: So that the only factor affecting erosion was the steepness of the slope; different water volumes would add another variable and make the test unfair.
answers.explanation: Controlling variables is essential to a fair test.

questions.question: Draw a labelled diagram showing how water eroded the sand in the steep-slope tray. Include arrows for water flow direction and labels for ‘eroded channel’ and ‘deposited sand’.

answers.content: Diagram should show: (1) sloping tray, (2) river/channel widened or deepened, (3) arrows indicating fast water flow down the slope, (4) accumulation of sand at the tray’s lower end labelled ‘deposited sand’.

questions.question: Reducing the speed limit for motorboats near shorelines would MOST likely:

answers.content: Increase the force of waves and speed up erosion
answers.explanation: Lower speed produces smaller waves.

answers.content: Have no effect on shoreline erosion
answers.explanation: Wave size and force are linked to boat speed.

answers.content: Decrease the force of waves and slow down erosion
answers.explanation: Smaller, less energetic waves cause less sediment movement.

answers.content: Stop weathering processes on rocks
answers.explanation: Boat speed does not influence chemical or physical weathering of rocks.
